Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Topological Invariants for Enhanced Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Topological Data Analysis (TDA) emerged over the past decade as a powerful alternative to the mainstream tools of data analysis. Informally stated, the main premise of the TDA is that the data in any given problem have a shape, and this shape matters, describing what classes of models should be used. The shapes of data often reveal otherwise hidden patterns which characterize the underlying process, thus providing us with more insight into the phenomenon under investigation. Most of the work in topological data analysis has been focused on global properties of data. However, local structures permeating complex data sets, and in particular the distribution of different local structures within the data, can provide a wealth of additional information crucial to understanding of the underlying process. The proposed work aims at creating a collection of tools, together with theoretical guarantees and algorithmic instruments, allowing one to define and compute local topological structure of the datasets.

The theoretical results which the principal investigators aim to prove would involve the estimates on the probability of correct local topology recovery for random noisy samples from the underlying space, from non-uniform or irregular distributions. The algorithms and software tools developed within this proposal will be tested and honed on several problems of data analysis stemming from topics at the forefront of modern science or engineering. More specifically, the PIs intend to (1) develop mathematical tools for describing local topological structures in data; (2) develop methods for understanding behavior of local topological invariants across scales; (3) study local topological invariants of random functions, which is an important step towards quantifying local topological structure of pure noise; (4) develop robust, local topology based methods for capturing transient behavior (e.g. phase transitions) in dynamical systems. To illustrate and validate the obtained results, they will be employed to (1) capture transient behavior in power networks, such as onset of dangerous oscillations; (2) characterize complex networks, in particular, the Internet and plant root systems; (3) investigate brain activity, with the focus on neural characteristics of various tinnitus related conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As more and more scientific fields rely heavily on information extracted from the vast and continuously growing amounts of available data, new approached to data analysis have emerged which employ techniques and concepts from traditionally "data shy" mathematical areas. Topological data analysis is one of such approaches. It has already been successfully used in may scientific disciplines, but it is still in its early stages of development. The main premise of the topological data analysis is that data have shape, and understanding this shape is key to developing more powerful data analysis methods. It should be noted that shape can mean many different things. Most topological data analysis tools focus on the global shape of data, more specifically, the global homology of data. The latter, to appeal to a contrived but illustrative example, allows us to distinguish patterns of data in the shape of a doughnut versus the ones in the shape of a malasada. However, one can also consider the notion of local shape (based on the mathematical concept of local homology), since complex data sets potentially contain many regions where certain transitions in the shape of surrounding data happen. Efficiently capturing such local structures and their distributions would provide a wealth of new information about the data.

As a part of the project, we obtained results that provide a theoretical foundation for recovering local homology information from potentially noisy samples whose underlying space can be fairly complicated. These results give conditions that guarantee correct local homology recovery at certain scales and explain when and where the correct local homology recovery may not be possible. Importantly, computations of local homology estimates can be done using well known and efficient approaches. In addition, we developed a novel approach to handling multiple scales in out computations. It employs a reduced number of scales represented in a new way to significantly improve computational efficiency. Moreover, it can potentially help us better understand how local homology changes across scales. We applied our topological data analysis techniques to assess the structure of the network representing the Internet, climate data, and microbiome data. The work on practical application has led to several ongoing collaborations. Some of our work have already been published in peer reviewed journals, with more publications in the pipeline. Also, the project helped us train graduate and undergraduate students in various aspects of data science.
